DM11:07am

The Audi e-tron will be officially unveiled in August at a stand-alone event. This year in Geneva it is hidden under a cover, but was unveiled for several minutes yesterday (see picture). Though the colours aren't quite final, the model as we witnessed it is the version that will go into volume production this year. It will be Audi's first major BEV and compete with the Jaguar i-Pace, Tesla Model X and from year-end 2018 also the Mercedes EQ. IHS forecasts 24k units next year; we think it could be more.

The Vizzion is VW's latest autonomous study. With a sleek interior and interior comparable by size to the Phaeton, VW is considering launching it as early as 2022 as a level 4 autonomous car (i.e., with full self-driving capabilities but still a steering wheel) and by 2025 entirely without any driving controls. Could this be (one of) VW's first robo-taxis in 7 years?

Domino's Pizza reported 52-wk PBT growth of 10% to £94.4m, 3% ahead of consensus, with key drivers including +4.8% LFL and a record 95 store openings in the UK, with franchisee store profitability unchanged. Current trading is encouraging at +7.1% LFL, particularly in light of trading in the wider restaurant sector. Domino's remains highly cash generative able to support selective M&A and capital returns. The shares are -8% ytd and trade on 19.1x 2018E PER with double digit earning growth. BUY.

RA morning kids

11:18 am
DM11:19am

There are a lot of moving parts in these results. While the underlying numbers look robust, there are material exceptional charges, a material HMRC provision and other exceptional charges that require further questions. Despite record breaking store openings and positive LFLs, UK &ROI margins went backwards which only increases the weight of our concerns.

DM11:19am

Group segmental profit margin declined 50bps YoY to 7.8% of system sales despite record breaking openings and decent LFLs. The rate of openings in FY18 has been guided to lower to 65-75 which we feel could be the start of a slow-down in openings as franchisee profitability and cash flows come under even more pressure. These results require time to decipher and work-through. We see nothing to change our view.

BE11:27am

Rather than type myself, here's Barclays to summarise.

BE11:27am

Aviva reported operating earnings growth of +2% YoY to £3,068 (ahead of consensus of £3,040), and EPS growth of 7% to 54.8p (consensus 53.0p). The higher EPS growth is driven by a lower tax rate, lower minority interest and impact of £300m FY2017 buyback. Operating profit from continuing operations increased 6% YoY. The dividend has increased 18% to 27.4p (consensus 26.4p), a 50% payout and equivalent to 5.2% yield. The company has not announced a buyback as hoped, but reiterated its target of returning £2bn of capital in 2018 (£900m repaying debt) – the delay in announcing details of a capital return is because the company is considering paying down £450m of preference shares (7.85% to 8.75% coupon), which won’t impact EPS but will free up cash for underlying ordinary dividend increases.

BE11:27am

Aviva reiterated its aim to grow EPS by 5% per annum, but it has effectively brought forward the base to grow EPS from 2017's base level of 54.8p (previously it was from 2018 base after the dilution from the asset sales). This is effectively an upgrade on 2018 EPS guidance. The earnings beat was partly driven by £290m of one-offs (vs £151m in 2015 and normal range of £150 to £200m, including £700m longevity release). However, Canada earnings declined by 83% or £220m to £46m – Canadian insurer Intact has faced similar issues on higher claims inflation– Aviva has taken pricing actions which will start to come through in 2018.

Flaneur @red - you couldnt be more wrong about that. Sorry.@Forester - Izzy wrote a piece recently on this, it had a..... different view..@Phil - I'd concur with that. Unfortunately its likely they are counted in official stats though..
11:27 am
BE11:28am

While 2017 earnings themselves were mixed (higher management actions / longevity release offsetting weaker Canada), we think the guidance that the company expects to grow EPS by at least 5% from 2017 base of 54.8p is positive – this would suggest EPS of at least c57.5p and c60.4p in 2018 and 2019 (5% growth per annum on 2017), versus our current estimates of 56.8p for FY18 and 60.4p for FY19. The fact the company is considering paying down the preference shares, instead of debt or share buybacks is also a positive. Economically (given the c9% coupon), paying down the preference shares makes sense, but it does not impact EPS like a debt buyback (reducing interest costs) or a stock buyback (reducing share count and hence increasing EPS). The company is focused on doing the right thing, even if it doesn’t boost underlying metrics. Only when a company is on the front foot can it make these decisions. We reiterate our Overweight recommendation, the stock is trading on 10x FY18 estimate and a 5% yield.

Soundbuy @Phil - agreed, was wondering how many were courier Cos. - hard to scratch a living I've heard and high staff turnover rates...

We see Aviva's target upgrades (at its Investor Day in November) as steps in the right direction and believe in management's ability to deliver on them. However, while Aviva may look cheap vs the UK life sector, trading on 2018e P/E of 10.1x (vs UK life at 11.6x), it trades broadly in line with European Composites (at 10.5x), and offers an in-line dividend yield of c.5%. We prefer AXA and Generali, which trade on 8.4x and 9.5x respectively despite offering better growth potential. Hold rating reiterated.

Barclays, which I'm pretty sure is shop, have done this:

BE11:40am

With tough FX in the final quarter Alfa’s FY results were a touch light of our estimates, with revenues 2.5%, EBIT 1.7% and EPS 3.2% behind. Growth, as anticipated, slowed in the 2H as some large contracts matured and it had a tough comp. This will be mirrored in 2018 with a weaker 1H and 2H rapidly accelerating on the back of recent signings. It is guiding to mid double-digit const. FX revenue growth and we calculate ~4% FX headwind. We reflect this in our estimates, leading to ’18 revenue and EPS downgrades of 4% and 8%, respectively. The downgrades are partly FX and partly phasing, which is result in FY19E growth improving and leading to modest adjustments of -1% to revenues and -3% to EPS.

The sales pipeline in 2018 is significantly below (a double-
digit decline) the prior year and H1 EBITDA is expected to be c£10m below the prior year and unlikely to be recovered by the year end. This implies EBITDA of c£55m for 2018 – a downgrade of c25% on our current forecast of £74m. A turnaround strategy has been put in place by management, going ‘back to basics', including a withdrawal from the hybrid digital offering that the group had rolled out into 50% of its branch network over the last few years. Further details of the turnaround strategy are to be announced at the interims in August. There are a lot of moving parts here, both in terms of the soft trading backdrop and the uncertainty surrounding the overall shape of the business going forward. Management believes the business is ‘fixable’, but it is not just 2018 that will present challenges as the impending 2019 lettings fee ban (over £20m of annual revenue) leaves the group facing problems for at least the next two years.
